The Director, Collection Policy, is responsible for all policies and within the Offer in Compromise program. The National Program Manager, Offer in Compromise, is responsible for opment and delivery of policies and procedures within the program. IRM authors are responsible for writing policies and procedures and documents through all affected offices. Offer in compromise employees responsible for initial case processing of receipts are responsible for following the procedures in this IRM. Operational and program reviews are conducted on a yearly basis with the of data and reports from the Automated Offer in Compromise (AOIC) and Integrated Collection System (ICS). See IRM
, Offer in Manager’s Resource Guide.
Offer in compromise employees responsible for initial case processing of OIC receipts are responsible for following the procedures in this IRM.
AOIC Inventory Management Listing, Inventory Listing and Undetermined Offers Listing reports are utilized to monitor OIC cases.

The following table is a list of common abbreviations, acronyms and deﬁnitions used throughout this IRM. Other common abbreviations can be found at: http:// rnet.web.irs.gov/Resources/AcronymsDatabase.aspx Acronym database
5.8.2.1.6 (09-02-2022) Terms/Deﬁnitions/ Acronyms

Acronym Deﬁnition AOIC – Automated Offer in Com- Computer application where offers promise in compromise are recorded and monitored from receipt to closure. History of the offer investigations conducted by COIC employees and of actions taken by Monitoring OIC (MOIC) units are also main- tained on this system. CDP – Collection Due Process Allows taxpayers a right to a hearing before Appeals regarding proposed collection enforcement actions or ﬁled Notice of Federal Tax Lien. COIC – Centralized Offer in Employees located in Brookhaven Compromise and Memphis campuses that complete initial processing. CSED – Collection Statute Expi- The date the statutory period for ration Date collecting the tax expires. DATC – Doubt as to Collectibility Basis for acceptance of an offer where there is doubt that the tax can be paid in full. DATL – Doubt as to Liability Basis for acceptance of an offer where there is doubt that the liability is correct.
Centralized Offer in Compromise Initial Processing and Processability 5.8.2

5.8.2 page 3 Acronym Deﬁnition ETA – Effective Tax Administra- Basis for acceptance of an offer tion where this is no doubt that the liability is correct or can be paid in full. However, requiring the taxpayer to fully pay the tax would either create an economic hardship or be a public policy/ equity issue. IAT - Integrated Automation IAT tools interact with IDRS to Technologies automate daily tasks. ICS - Integrated Collection Computer application used by System Compliance employees to monitor inventory. Histories of OIC investi- gations conducted by area office employees are maintained on this system. MOIC – Monitoring OIC Unit Tax Examiners located in Brookhaven and Memphis campuses that complete end pro- cessing and monitor accepted offers for payments and compli- ance for 5 years. OE – Offer Examiner An examiner appointed as an offer investigator and located in COIC. OS – Offer Specialist A revenue officer appointed as an offer investigator, generally located in an ﬁeld office. PE – Process Examiner Completes initial processability determinations on offers and is located in COIC. SCOIC Speciality Collection Offer in Com- promise SRP - Shared Responsibility Beginning in 2014, IRC 5000A Payment required all individuals to have qualifying health care coverage (called minimum essential coverage or MEC) in each month of the year, qualify for an exemption, or make an individual shared responsibility payment (SRP) when they ﬁle their tax return for the year.

5.8 Offer in Acronym Deﬁnition TFRP – Trust Fund Recovery Assessments made on individual Penalty taxpayers for the withheld or trust fund portion of delinquent employ- ment taxes. TIPRA – Tax Increase Prevention Legislation enacted in May, 2006, and Reconciliation Act of 2005 which made major changes to the OIC program.

, Records and Information Management Records Control Schedules, for record retention. The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC

), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional infor- mation about TBOR, see https://www.irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights Taxpayers have the right to expect the tax system to consider facts and circumstances that might affect their underlying liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information timely. Taxpayers have the right to re- ceive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service if they are experi- encing ﬁnancial difficulty or if the IRS has not resolved their tax issues properly and timely through its normal channels. (TIPRA) was signed into law on May
See IRM
, The Tax Increase Preven- tion and Reconciliation Act of
for additional information. The law stipulates that, in addition to the application fee, an Offer in Compro- mise (OIC) received on or after July
, must include one of the following based on the offer terms. a. Lump Sum Cash – The submission of any lump sum OIC shall be ac- companied by
% of the amount of the offer or the low-income certiﬁcation box checked on Form
As a matter of policy, the term “lump sum” means any offer of payments made in
or fewer installments within ﬁve months of offer acceptance, unless an exception as noted in IRM
under Payments exists. Enter a “C” (Cash) on the Automated Offer in Compromise (AOIC) “Terms” screen if the payments will be made in
or fewer months. or a deferred “D” (Deferred) if the payments will be completed in more than
months. b. Periodic Payment – The submission of any periodic payment OIC shall be accompanied by the amount of the ﬁrst proposed installment or the low-income certiﬁcation box checked on Form
. As a matter of policy, the term “periodic payment” means any offer of payments in

months. Enter a “D” (Deferred) on the AOIC Terms screen. Taxpayers can forward offer payments through Electronic Federal Tax
PE will annotate “EFTPS” or “DP” in the check number ﬁeld on AOIC. The PE is to ensure the payments are posted correctly avoiding any erroneous refunds. (

) The required initial payment and subsequent payments will be applied to the taxpayer’s account, whether the offer is deemed processable or not process- able. These funds are non-refundable, except for some situations, and should be immediately posted to the taxpayer’s account (either as designated by the taxpayer or to the government’s best interest if not designated). This does include deposits or application fees. Effective with the Form
revision on

, deposits are no longer accepted if the taxpayer submits a deposit, draw a diagonal line across the check and write “Return” across the check send back to the taxpayer with the return letter. Application fees may not be designated but may be refundable, in certain situations. (

) Because a taxpayer may not specify how the application fee for processing offer in compromise will be applied, the service will apply the application fee the best interest of the government. See IRM
, Processable Offers - Payment Processing. (
